form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mrs. Shaheen (for herself and Mr. Vitter) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship

form.official-title: To improve certain programs of the Small Business Administration to better assist small business customers in accessing broadband technology, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Small Business Broadband and Emerging Information Technology Enhancement Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: According to a report by the Federal Communications Commission entitled Connecting America: The National Broadband Plan, dated March 2010, the Commission recommends that—

subparagraph.text: To fully implement next-generation technology within its operations, the SBA should also appoint a broadband and emerging IT coordinator. This individual would ensure that SBA programs maintain the requisite broadband expertise, tools and training courses to serve small businesses.;
Congress should consider ways to leverage existing assistance provided through entrepreneurial development programs, to focus training on advanced IT and broadband applications;
Congress could also consider ways to support technology training among women entrepreneurs through women’s business centers;

The training programs should include an entry-level Broadband 101 course to give small businesses an introduction to how to capitalize on broadband connectivity, as well as more advanced applications for IT staff.; and

small and medium enterprise IT training should include resources for non-IT staff, such as how to use e-commerce tools for sales, streamline finance with online records or leverage knowledge management across an organization..

paragraph.text: According to a report by the Broadband Opportunity Council, dated August 20, 2015, the Council recommends that the United States—

subparagraph.text: modernize Federal programs to expand program support for broadband technology investments;
empower communities with tools and resources to attract investment in and promote meaningful use of broadband technology;
promote increased deployment of and competition relating to broadband technology through expanded access to Federal assets; and
improve data collection, analysis, and research on broadband technology.

paragraph.text: According to a report entitled The State of the App Economy, dated October 2014—

subparagraph.text: More than three-quarters of the highest grossing apps are produced by startups and small companies.; and
Seventy-eight percent of the leading app companies are located outside Silicon Valley..

paragraph.text: According to a report entitled, Developer Economics Q1 2015: State of the Developer Nation, dated February 2015, The emergence of the app industry over the past eight years has grown to a $120 billion economy..

section.header: Broadband and emerging information technology coordinator
section.text: The Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 631 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating section 47 as section 48; and
by inserting after section 46 the following:
the term Associate Administrator means the Associate Administrator for the Office of Investment and Innovation; and

the term broadband and emerging information technology coordinator means the employee designated to carry out the broadband and emerging information technology coordination responsibilities of the Administration under subsection (b)(1).
The Associate Administrator shall designate a senior employee of the Office of Investment and Innovation to serve as the broadband and emerging information technology coordinator, who—

subparagraph.text: shall report to the Associate Administrator;
shall work in coordination with—

clause.text: the chief information officer, the chief technology officer, and the head of the Office of Technology of the Administration; and
any other Associate Administrator of the Administration determined appropriate by the Associate Administrator;

subparagraph.text: has experience developing and implementing telecommunications policy in the private sector or government; and
has demonstrated significant experience in the area of broadband or emerging information technology.

paragraph.text: The broadband and emerging information technology coordinator shall—

subparagraph.text: coordinate programs of the Administration that assist small business concerns in adopting, making innovations in, and using broadband and other emerging information technologies;

serve as the primary liaison of the Administration to other Federal agencies involved in broadband and emerging information technology policy, including the Department of Commerce, the Department of Agriculture, and the Federal Communications Commission;
identify best practices relating to broadband and emerging information technology that may benefit small business concerns; and

identify and catalog tools and training available through the resource partners of the Administration that assist small business concerns in adopting, making innovations in, and using broadband and emerging technologies.

paragraph.text: Not more than 20 percent of the hours of service by the broadband and emerging information technology coordinator during any fiscal year shall consist of travel outside the United States to perform official duties.
The Associate Administrator shall provide to employees of the Administration training that—

subparagraph.text: familiarizes employees of the Administration with broadband and other emerging information technologies;
includes—

clause.text: instruction on counseling small business concerns regarding adopting, making innovations in, and using broadband and other emerging information technologies; and
information on programs of the Federal Government that provide assistance to small business concerns relating to broadband and emerging information technologies; and

subparagraph.text: to maximum extent practicable, uses the tools and training cataloged and identified under subsection (b)(2)(D).

paragraph.text: There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as are necessary to carry out this subsection.

Not later than 2 years after the date on which the Associate Administrator makes the first designation of an employee under subsection (b), and every 2 years thereafter, the broadband and emerging information technology coordinator shall submit to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate and the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives a report regarding the programs and activities of the Administration relating to broadband and other emerging information technologies.

paragraph.header: Impact of broadband speed and price on small businesses

subparagraph.text: Subject to appropriations, the Chief Counsel for Advocacy shall conduct a study evaluating the impact of broadband speed and price on small business concerns.

Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of the Small Business Broadband and Emerging Information Technology Enhancement Act of 2015, the Chief Counsel for Advocacy shall submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate and the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives a report on the results of the study under subparagraph (A), including—

clause.text: a survey of broadband speeds available to small business concerns;
a survey of the cost of broadband speeds available to small business concerns;
a survey of the type of broadband technology used by small business concerns; and
any policy recommendations that may improve the access of small business concerns to comparable broadband services at comparable rates in all regions of the United States.

section.text: Section 21(c)(3)(B) of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 648(c)(3)(B)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in the matter preceding clause (i), by inserting accessing broadband and other emerging information technology, after technology transfer,;
in clause (ii), by striking and at the end;
in clause (iii), by adding and at the end; and
by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: increasing the competitiveness and productivity of small business concerns by assisting entrepreneurs in accessing broadband and other emerging information technology;
